item.title: DS and Algo Sessions: Check if a tree is BST or not
item.content:encoded:
Introduction and Problem Statement

A BST stands or binary search tree. It is a tree data structure. It has the following properties

  • All child node of a left subtree will contain a key value less than the current node’s key.
  • All child node of a right subtree will contain a key value greater than the current node’s key.

We have to check if a tree is BST or not. For a tree to be BST, it must satisfy the above-given properties.

Implementation

We need to create a function which will take the root node of the tree as an argument and it will return True if the given tree is BST else it will return false. Given that node of a tree is defined as:

class node:
  def __init__(self, data):
      self.data = data
      self.left = None
      self.right = None

We will use recursion to solve this. Every time we jump from one node to other we will assume that node to be a new tree and solve in the following pattern. But if we use recursion then we might also need to check what is the minimum and maximum value in that particular subtree. If we are in left subtree then the minimum value will be as much less as possible but the maximum value will be one less than that of the parent node. Same goes for the right subtree, the minimum value will be one greater than the parent node’s value and maximum value will be as much large as possible. With each recursive call, we will keep updating the minimum and maximum value. The proper code is given below.

def isBST(node):
    minVal=-999999
    maxVal=999999
    return checkBST(node,minVal,maxVal)
def checkBST(node,minVal,maxVal):
    if root is None:
        return True
    elif root.left<minVal or root.right>maxVal:
        return False
    else:
        return (chekcBST(node.left,minVal,node.data-1) and checkBST(node.right,node.data+1,maxVal))
